natural problem: A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$?
natural solution: There are 13 $\heartsuit$'s and 52 cards total, so the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$ is $\dfrac{13}{52} = \boxed{\dfrac14}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P 52 = 1"
and h1 : "P 13 = 1/4"
shows  "P (the (card_of {x. x in hearts})) = 1/4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$? The final Answer is \dfrac14
 ### Proof
 There are 13 $\heartsuit$'s and 52 cards total, so the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$ is $\dfrac{13}{52} = \boxed{\dfrac14}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P 52 = 1"
and h1 : "P 13 = 1/4"
shows  "P (the (card_of {x. x in hearts})) = 1/4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a function P that maps natural numbers to real numbers, if P(52) equals 1 and P(13) equals 1/4, find the value of P for the number of cards in a suit of a standard deck of playing cards (hearts). The final answer is 1/4.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cards :: "nat set" 
and hearts :: "nat set" 
assumes h0 : "cards = {1..52}"
and h1 : "hearts = {1..13}"
and h2 : "hearts ⊆ cards"
shows  "card hearts / card cards = 1/4"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$? The final Answer is \dfrac14
 ### Proof
 There are 13 $\heartsuit$'s and 52 cards total, so the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$ is $\dfrac{13}{52} = \boxed{\dfrac14}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cards :: "nat set" 
and hearts :: "nat set" 
assumes h0 : "cards = {1..52}"
and h1 : "hearts = {1..13}"
and h2 : "hearts ⊆ cards"
shows  "card hearts / card cards = 1/4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a standard deck of 52 playing cards, there are 13 hearts. What fraction of the deck is made up of hearts? The final answer is $\frac{1}{4}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_cards total_hearts :: real
assumes h0 : "total_cards = 52"
and h1 : "total_hearts = 13"
shows  "total_hearts / total_cards = 1 / 4"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$? The final Answer is \dfrac14
 ### Proof
 There are 13 $\heartsuit$'s and 52 cards total, so the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$ is $\dfrac{13}{52} = \boxed{\dfrac14}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_cards total_hearts :: real
assumes h0 : "total_cards = 52"
and h1 : "total_hearts = 13"
shows  "total_hearts / total_cards = 1 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: "What fraction of a 52-card deck is made up of hearts? The final answer is 1/4."

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
assumes h0 : "let deck = 52; ranks = 13; suits = 4; black_suits = 2; red_suits = 2 in
suits = black_suits + red_suits \<and> deck = ranks * suits"
shows  "let heart_cards = 13; deck = 52 in heart_cards / deck = 1/4"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$? The final Answer is \dfrac14
 ### Proof
 There are 13 $\heartsuit$'s and 52 cards total, so the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$ is $\dfrac{13}{52} = \boxed{\dfrac14}$.
 *)

theorem
assumes h0 : "let deck = 52; ranks = 13; suits = 4; black_suits = 2; red_suits = 2 in
suits = black_suits + red_suits \<and> deck = ranks * suits"
shows  "let heart_cards = 13; deck = 52 in heart_cards / deck = 1/4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Assuming a standard deck of 52 cards with 13 different ranks and 4 different suits (of which 2 are black and 2 are red), if there are 13 heart cards in the deck, what is the fraction of heart cards in the deck? The final answer is 1/4.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cards :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "card {suits. suits = 1..4} = 4"
and h1 : "card {ranks. ranks = 1..13} = 13"
and h2 : "\<forall>suits ranks. 1 \<le> suits \<and> suits \<le> 4 \<and> 1 \<le> ranks \<and> ranks \<le> 13 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>!card. cards suits ranks = card)"
and h3 : "card {suits. \<exists>ranks. cards suits ranks = card \<and> suits = 2} = 13"
shows  "card {suits. \<exists>ranks. cards suits ranks = card \<and> suits = 2} / card (UNIV :: nat set) = 1 / 4"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$? The final Answer is \dfrac14
 ### Proof
 There are 13 $\heartsuit$'s and 52 cards total, so the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$ is $\dfrac{13}{52} = \boxed{\dfrac14}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes cards :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "card {suits. suits = 1..4} = 4"
and h1 : "card {ranks. ranks = 1..13} = 13"
and h2 : "\<forall>suits ranks. 1 \<le> suits \<and> suits \<le> 4 \<and> 1 \<le> ranks \<and> ranks \<le> 13 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>!card. cards suits ranks = card)"
and h3 : "card {suits. \<exists>ranks. cards suits ranks = card \<and> suits = 2} = 13"
shows  "card {suits. \<exists>ranks. cards suits ranks = card \<and> suits = 2} / card (UNIV :: nat set) = 1 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A standard deck of cards has 4 suits and each suit has 13 ranks. If each card in the deck can be uniquely defined by its suit and rank, and there are 13 cards with suit 2, what is the fraction of the entire deck that these cards represent? The answer is 1/4.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes black red :: real
assumes h0 : "black = 26"
and h1 : "red = 26"
and h2 : "black + red = 52"
shows  "red / (black + red) = 1 / 4"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$? The final Answer is \dfrac14
 ### Proof
 There are 13 $\heartsuit$'s and 52 cards total, so the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$ is $\dfrac{13}{52} = \boxed{\dfrac14}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes black red :: real
assumes h0 : "black = 26"
and h1 : "red = 26"
and h2 : "black + red = 52"
shows  "red / (black + red) = 1 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given that there are 26 black and 26 red balls, if the total number of balls is 52, find the fraction of red balls in the total number of balls. The final answer is 1/4.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 <= p"
and h1 : "p <= 1"
and h2 : "p = 1 / 4"
shows  "p = probability (\<lambda>x. suit x = Hearts) (standard_deck 52)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$? The final Answer is \dfrac14
 ### Proof
 There are 13 $\heartsuit$'s and 52 cards total, so the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$ is $\dfrac{13}{52} = \boxed{\dfrac14}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 <= p"
and h1 : "p <= 1"
and h2 : "p = 1 / 4"
shows  "p = probability (\<lambda>x. suit x = Hearts) (standard_deck 52)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: The probability of drawing a heart from a standard deck of 52 cards is 1/4.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes deck :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "deck = 52"
and h1 : "\<forall> suit. suit = deck div 4"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>card. card = suit \<and> suit = 'heartsuit') = 1 / 4"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$? The final Answer is \dfrac14
 ### Proof
 There are 13 $\heartsuit$'s and 52 cards total, so the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$ is $\dfrac{13}{52} = \boxed{\dfrac14}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes deck :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "deck = 52"
and h1 : "\<forall> suit. suit = deck div 4"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>card. card = suit \<and> suit = 'heartsuit') = 1 / 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a standard deck of 52 cards, what is the probability of drawing a heart? The final answer is 1/4.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = 1/4"
shows  "prob {card. suit card = Hearts} = p"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$? The final Answer is \dfrac14
 ### Proof
 There are 13 $\heartsuit$'s and 52 cards total, so the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$ is $\dfrac{13}{52} = \boxed{\dfrac14}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = 1/4"
shows  "prob {card. suit card = Hearts} = p"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: The probability of drawing a card from a standard deck of 52 cards where the suit of the card is Hearts is 1/4.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes card :: "(suit, rank) prod set"
and black :: "(suit, rank) prod set"
and red :: "(suit, rank) prod set"
and hearts :: "(suit, rank) prod set"
assumes h0 : "card = black \<union> red"
and h1 : "black \<inter> red = {}"
and h2 : "hearts \<subseteq> red"
and h3 : "finite card"
and h4 : "card \<noteq> {}"
shows  "card (UNIV :: suit set) (UNIV :: rank set) = 52"
and "card black (UNIV :: rank set) = 26"
and "card red (UNIV :: rank set) = 26"
and "card hearts (UNIV :: rank set) = 13"
and "prob_space.prob card (hearts \<times> UNIV) = 1/4"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A standard deck of 52 cards has 13 ranks (Ace, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King) and 4 suits ($\spadesuit$, $\heartsuit$, $\diamondsuit$, and $\clubsuit$), such that there is exactly one card for any given rank and suit.  Two of the suits ($\spadesuit$ and $\clubsuit$) are black and the other two suits ($\heartsuit$ and $\diamondsuit$) are red.  The deck is randomly arranged. What is the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$? The final Answer is \dfrac14
 ### Proof
 There are 13 $\heartsuit$'s and 52 cards total, so the probability that the top card is a $\heartsuit$ is $\dfrac{13}{52} = \boxed{\dfrac14}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes card :: "(suit, rank) prod set"
and black :: "(suit, rank) prod set"
and red :: "(suit, rank) prod set"
and hearts :: "(suit, rank) prod set"
assumes h0 : "card = black \<union> red"
and h1 : "black \<inter> red = {}"
and h2 : "hearts \<subseteq> red"
and h3 : "finite card"
and h4 : "card \<noteq> {}"
shows  "card (UNIV :: suit set) (UNIV :: rank set) = 52"
and "card black (UNIV :: rank set) = 26"
and "card red (UNIV :: rank set) = 26"
and "card hearts (UNIV :: rank set) = 13"
and "prob_space.prob card (hearts \<times> UNIV) = 1/4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a deck of 52 cards which are divided into red and black suits. The deck is not empty and the sets of red and black cards do not intersect, i.e., no card belongs to both the red and black sets. The suit of hearts is a subset of the red set. The deck is finite and the total number of cards is 52, with 26 red cards, 26 black cards and 13 hearts. What is the probability of drawing a heart from the deck? The answer is 1/4.
